statement:
The *Clarkson inequality* says that for all $f,g \in L^p$, for
$2\leq p<\infty$ we have: $$\left\| \frac{f+g}{2} \right\|^p_p +
\left\| \frac{f-g}{2} \right\|^p_p
                                     \le
\frac{1}{2}\left( \|f\|^p_p + \|g\|^p_p\right).$$\
The inequality can be used to prove that $L^p$ space is uniformly convex
for $2\leq p<\infty$.

**Remark**. If $1 < p < 2$, then the Clarkson inequality becomes:
$$\left\| \frac{f+g}{2} \right\|^q_p +
\left\| \frac{f-g}{2} \right\|^q_p
                                     \le
\left(\frac{1}{2} \|f\|^p_p +\frac{1}{2} \|g\|^p_p\right)^\frac{1}{p-1}$$.

for functions $f,\,g \in L^p$, where $q=\frac{p}{p-1}$.
